Package com.rapidminer.belt.table

Class Table

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.rapidminer.belt.table.Table
  • public final class Table
extends java.lang.Object
    Immutable table using a column-oriented data layout. Values can be read either column-wise (recommended) or row-wise using the readers provided by the Readers class.
    Author:
    Michael Knopf

      • columns

        public Table columns​(int[] columns)
        Creates a new table consisting of the given columns. The column index array must contain valid indices only (i.e., values in the range [0, width())) and must not contain duplicates.
        Parameters:
        columns - the column indices
        Returns:
        the new table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the index array is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index array contains invalid indices
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the index array contains duplicates

      • columns

        Parameters:
        columns - the column labels
        Returns:
        the new table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the given label list is or contains null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the label list contains duplicates

      • rows

        public Table rows​(int[] rows,
                  Context ctx)
        Creates a new table with rows reordered according to the given row set using the given execution context. If the mapping contains invalid indices (i.e., values outside of the range [0, size())), the new table will contain missing value at that place. In particular, sub- and supersets, as well as duplicate indices are supported.
        Parameters:
        rows - the rows to select
        ctx - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the new table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the context or row index array is null

      • rows

        public Table rows​(int[] rows,
                  boolean view,
                  Context ctx)
        Creates a new table with rows reordered according to the given row set using the given execution context. If the mapping contains invalid indices (i.e., values outside of the range [0, size())), the new table will contain missing value at that place. In particular, sub- and supersets, as well as duplicate indices are supported.
        Parameters:
        rows - the rows to select
        view - if this is true the data will not be copied, only a view will be attached. Otherwise a heuristic is applied that might decide to copy the rows into a new table. Set this to true in case of several calls to this method for the same table.
        ctx - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the new table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the context or row index array is null

      • rows

        public Table rows​(int from,
                  int to,
                  Context ctx)
        Selects the rows from the given range [from, to).
        Parameters:
        from - the start of the range (inclusive)
        to - the end of the range (exclusive)
        ctx - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the new table with rows from the given range
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the context is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if start is not a valid row index
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the start is bigger than the end or the end bigger than the height

      • sort

        public Table sort​(int column,
                  Order order,
                  Context context)
        Creates a new table task to sort the table by the given column using the given sorting order and execution context.
        Parameters:
        column - the column to sort by
        order - the sorting order
        context - the execution context
        Returns:
        the task to sort the table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the order or context is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the column index is invalid

      • sort

        public Table sort​(int[] columns,
                  Order order,
                  Context context)
        Creates a new table sorted by the given columns using the given sorting order and execution context. If multiple columns are specified, the output is equivalent to sorting the entire table by the first column, then subsets of the same value by the second column, etc.
        Parameters:
        columns - the columns to sort by
        order - the sorting order
        context - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the sorted table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the column index array, order, or context is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the column index array contains an invalid index

      • sort

        public Table sort​(int[] columns,
                  java.util.List<Order> orders,
                  Context context)
        Creates a new table sorted by the given columns using the given sorting orders and execution context. If multiple columns are specified, the output is equivalent to sorting the entire table by the first column, then subsets of the same value by the second column, etc.

        This method assumes that a sorting order is specified for each of the given column indices, i.e., that the column index array and the order list are of the same size.

        Parameters:
        columns - the columns to sort by
        orders - the sorting orders
        context - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the sorted table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is or contains null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the column index array contains an invalid index
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the sizes of the orders and the column index array differ

      • sort

        public Table sort​(java.lang.String label,
                  Order order,
                  Context context)
        Creates a new table sorted by the given column using the given sorting order.
        Parameters:
        label - the column to sort by
        order - the sorting order
        context - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the sorted table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the label is invalid

      • sort

        public Table sort​(java.util.List<java.lang.String> columns,
                  Order order,
                  Context context)
        Creates a new table sorted by the given columns using the given sorting order and execution context. If multiple columns are specified, the output is equivalent to sorting the entire table by the first column, then subsets of the same value by the second column, etc.
        Parameters:
        columns - the columns to sort by
        order - the sorting order
        context - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the sorted table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is or contains null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the column labels contain an invalid label or is empty

      • sort

        public Table sort​(java.util.List<java.lang.String> columns,
                  java.util.List<Order> orders,
                  Context context)
        Creates a new table sorted by the given columns using the given sorting orders. If multiple columns are specified, the output is equivalent to sorting the entire table by the first column, then subsets of the same value by the second column, etc.

        This method assumes that a sorting order is specified for each of the given column indices, i.e., that the column index array and the order list are of the same size.

        Parameters:
        columns - the columns to sort by
        orders - the sorting orders
        context - the execution context to use
        Returns:
        the sorted table
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is or contains null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the column labels contain an invalid label, the label list is empty, or the label and sorting lists differ in size

      • rename

        public Table rename​(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,​java.lang.String> renamingMap)
        Creates a new table with old names replaced by those specified by the renaming map. This does also rename any ColumnReferences. Old names that are not in the table are ignored.
        Parameters:
        renamingMap - a map from old name to new name
        Returns:
        a new table with renamed columns
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the renaming map is null or contains null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a new name is invalid or already in use

        Returns:

      • filterNumeric

        public Table filterNumeric​(int column,
                           java.util.function.DoublePredicate predicate,
                           Workload workload,
                           Context context)
        Filters the table by the given filter predicate. Depending on the input size and the specified workload per data-point, the computation might be performed in parallel.
        Parameters:
        column - the index of the column on which to evaluate the predicate, must be Column.Capability.NUMERIC_READABLE
        predicate - the predicate to apply
        workload - the expected workload per data point
        context - the execution context
        Returns:
        a table with only those rows where the predicate returns true
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the predicate or context is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the column index is invalid

        workload - the expected workload per data point
        context - the execution context
        Returns:
        a table with only those rows where the predicate returns true

        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if any of the column indices is invalid

                               java.util.function.Predicate<CategoricalRow> filter,
                               Workload workload,
                               Context context)
        Filters the table by the given filter predicate. Depending on the input size and the specified workload per data-point, the computation might be performed in parallel.
        Parameters:
        columns - the label of the column on which to evaluate the predicate, must be Column.Category.CATEGORICAL
        filter - the predicate to apply
        workload - the expected workload per data point
        context - the execution context
        Returns:
        a table with only those rows where the predicate returns true
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if any of the arguments is or contains null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the column labels is invalid or the label list is empty

      • filterObjects

        public <T> Table filterObjects​(int column,
                               java.lang.Class<T> type,
                               java.util.function.Predicate<T> predicate,
                               Workload workload,
                               Context context)
        Filters the table by the given filter predicate. Depending on the input size and the specified workload per data-point, the computation might be performed in parallel.
        Parameters:
        column - the index of the column on which to evaluate the predicate, must be Column.Capability.OBJECT_READABLE of the given type
        type - the object type of the column
        predicate - the predicate to apply
        workload - the expected workload per data point
        context - the execution context
        Returns:
        a table with only those rows where the predicate returns true
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the predicate or context is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the column index is invalid

      • getMetaData

        public java.util.List<ColumnMetaData> getMetaData​(java.lang.String label)
        Returns the meta data attached to the column with the given label (if any).
        Parameters:
        label - the column label
        Returns:
        unmodifiable list of meta data
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the given label is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there is no column with the given label

      • getMetaData

        public <T extends ColumnMetaData> java.util.List<T> getMetaData​(java.lang.String label,
                                                                java.lang.Class<T> type)
        Returns the meta data with the given type attached to the column with the given label (if any).
        Parameters:
        label - the column label
        type - the meta data type
        Returns:
        the attached meta data
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the given label or type is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there is no column with the given label
        See Also:
        getFirstMetaData(String, Class)

      • getFirstMetaData

        public <T extends ColumnMetaData> T getFirstMetaData​(java.lang.String label,
                                                     java.lang.Class<T> type)
        Returns the first meta datum with the given type attached to the column with the given label (if any). Use of this method instead of getMetaData(String, Class) is recommended if it is known that there can be at most one match, e.g., if the meta data type has uniqueness level ColumnMetaData.Uniqueness.COLUMN.
        Parameters:
        label - the column label
        type - the meta data type
        Returns:
        the first attached meta datum or null
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the given label or type is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there is no column with the given label

      • select

        public ColumnSelector select()
        Creates a ColumnSelector for this table as a starting point for different column selection methods.
        Returns:
        a column selector for this table
        See Also:
        ColumnSelector

      • stripData

        public Table stripData()
        Creates a new table with the data stripped from the columns. All columns have length 0 and no views.
        Returns:
        a new table that only contains the schema information and no data

      • columnList

        public java.util.List<Column> columnList()
        Returns an immutable list of all table columns of this table.
        Returns:
        a list of all table columns
